title: 113_s1373
content:
The Act is titled the "Rebuilding American Homeownership Act of 2013" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act "Rebuilding American Homeownership Act of 2013" defines terms like "current borrower" as someone who has consistently made payments on their mortgage and "eligible mortgage" as an existing first mortgage. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency. An existing first mortgage with a current loan-to-value ratio between 80% and 140%, originated on or before May 31, 2009, not owned or guaranteed by an enterprise, and on a 1- to 4-family owner-occupied dwelling, is considered an eligible mortgage under the "Rebuilding American Homeownership Act of 2013." The term "enterprise" refers to the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The term "guarantee fee" has the same meaning as in section 1327(a) of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992. SEC. 3. REFINANCING AUTHORITY. Enterprise Refinancing Authority allows enterprises to establish programs for refinancing eligible mortgages, including purchasing, guaranteeing, servicing, selling, lending on the security of, and refinancing mortgages. Implementation Authority grants enterprises the power to set requirements and conditions for the refinancing program. The enterprise determines necessary criteria for the refinancing program, including verification of borrower's employment, income, credit history, property valuation, and continuation of junior liens on the property. Eligible mortgages with existing credit enhancement coverage must maintain it to participate in the program. The refinancing program requires eligible mortgages to maintain existing credit enhancement coverage or transfer it to the new mortgage. The new mortgage's term cannot exceed 30 years, and the loan amount must adhere to the maximum principal obligation limit for conventional mortgages. The Director has the authority to issue regulations and guidance. The Director has the authority to issue regulations, guidance, or directives necessary for the refinancing program. SEC. 4. GUARANTEE FEES. Each enterprise must charge a guarantee fee for ensuring timely payment on securities backed by eligible mortgages. The fee amount is determined by the Director to cover the expected default risk on the refinanced mortgages. The Director must ensure reasonable default probability assumptions for risk modeling and prohibit additional charges or offsets in determining guarantee fees for mortgage-backed securities. The Director has the authority to limit offers of guarantees on securities backed by eligible mortgages under this Act if they do not comply with the requirements of the section. SEC. 5. REPORTS.

The Director will report annually to Congress on the program's use and impact, including its effectiveness in reducing mortgage default rates, preventing foreclosure, and supporting stable homeownership, along with any recommendations. SEC. 6. SUNSET. The provisions of this Act will terminate on December 31, 2014, but the Director can extend them for a 1-year period with notification to Congress.
